title: Leo Bosschart
text:
Leonard ("Leo") François Gerard Bosschart (24 August 1888 in <a href="Banda%20Aceh">Kota Radja</a>, <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies">Dutch East Indies</a> – 9 May 1951 in <a href="Hoboken%2C%20Antwerp">Hoboken, Antwerp</a>, <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>) was a <a href="association%20football">football</a> player from the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>, who captained his home country at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201920%20Summer%20Olympics">1920 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Antwerp%2C%20Belgium">Antwerp, Belgium</a> as captain. There he won the bronze medal with the <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands national football team</a>.
Club career.
A versatile midfielder, Bosschart played for <a href="Quick%20Den%20Haag">Quick</a>.
International career.
Bosschart made his debut for <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands</a> in a December 1909 <a href="friendly%20match">friendly match</a> against <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> and earned a total of 19 caps, scoring 1 goal. His final international was a September 1920 friendly against <a href="Spain%20national%20football%20team">Spain</a>.
Personal life.
Born in the Dutch East Indies to Francois Guilleaume Jacques Bosschart and Anna Catharina Gerardina Eras, Bosschart studied engineering in Delft and became chief engineer at Burgenhout in <a href="Rotterdam">Rotterdam</a> and director of the Conrad shipyard. From 1938 until his death in 1951, Bosschart was director of the John Cockerill shipyard in Hoboken, Belgium.
